Manjunath Omana Kuttan

High Energy Physicist | Data Physicist

Post doctoral researcher at Frankfurt Institute for Advanced Studies, Germany

Member at KISS collaboration: Künstliche Intelligenz zur Schnellen Simulation von wissenschaftlichen Daten

BMBF projekt: AI for Fast Simulation of Scientific Data

  • more info

Latest News

Our recent work, "QCD Equation of State of Dense Nuclear Matter from a Bayesian Analysis of Heavy-Ion Collision Data," has been highlighted on the cover of Physical Review Letters and has been recommended as an editor's suggestion.

  • Learn more

Scientific Interests

My research focuses on:

  • Developing AI for high-energy physics, particularly in heavy-ion collisions.
  • DL applications ranging from data-driven physics inference to ultra-fast simulations.
  • Dynamics of nucleus-nucleus collisions from models & detector simulations.
  • Applying statistical methods to solve inverse problems.
  • Learn more

Education

  • Ph.D. in Physics, magna cum laude
    Johann Wolfgang Goethe-Universität, Frankfurt am Main, Germany (2019–2023) Dissertation: AI in heavy-ion collisions: bridging the gap between theory and experiments. Advisor: Prof. Dr. Dr. h.c. mult. Horst Stoecker

  • M.Sc. in Physics
    Central University of Karnataka, India (2017–2019)
    Thesis: Deep learning for muon momentum reconstruction for the INO-ICAL detector. Advisor: Prof. Dr. Deepak Samuel
  • Learn more

Research Experience

  • Postdoctoral Research:
    Ultra-fast simulation techniques for heavy-ion collisions in the KISS collaboration
  • Doctoral Research:
    • Explored Deep Learning and Bayesian methods to bridge theory and experiments
    • DL solutions for CBM,PANDA@FAIR, HADES@GSI, NA61@CERN, STAR@RHIC
    • Investigated time evolution in dynamical models for heavy-ion collisions
    • Mentored Master's students and organized international workshops
  • Master's Research:
    Thesis focused on Deep Learning for muon momentum reconstruction in the Indian neutrino project, along with gaining hands-on experience in:
    • Fabrication and testing of RPC detectors.
    • installation of prototype detector for the neutrino project.
  • Learn more

Selected Publications and Conferences

Selected Publications

M. Omana Kuttan, J. Steinheimer, K. Zhou, and H. Stoecker

“QCD Equation of State of Dense Nuclear Matter from a Bayesian Analysis of Heavy-Ion Collision Data,”
Phys. Rev. Lett., vol. 131, no. 20, p. 202 303, 2023.
Highlighted as cover for Volume 131, Issue 20, 2023. Recommended as Editor’s suggestion.

M. Omana Kuttan, A. Motornenko, J. Steinheimer, H. Stoecker, Y. Nara, and M. Bleicher

“A chiral mean-field equation-of-state in UrQMD: effects on the heavy ion compression stage,”
Eur. Phys. J. C, vol. 82, no. 5, p. 427, 2022.

M. Omana Kuttan, K. Zhou, J. Steinheimer, A. Redelbach, and H. Stoecker

“A fast centrality meter for heavy-ion collisions at the CBM experiment,”
Phys. Lett. B, vol. 811, p. 135 872, 2020.

M. Omana Kuttan, K. Zhou, J. Steinheimer, A. Redelbach, and H. Stoecker

“An equation of state meter for CBM using PointNet,”
JHEP, vol. 21, p. 184, 2020.

M. Omana Kuttan, J. Steinheimer, K. Zhou, M. Bleicher, and H. Stoecker

“Model dependence of the number of participant nucleons and observable consequences in heavy-ion collisions,”
Eur. Phys. J. C, vol. 83, no. 9, p. 792, 2023.

Selected Conferences and Workshops

Strangeness in Quark Matter, Strasbourg; June 2024;

Talk: Bayesian constraints on the high density QCD EoS from Heavy-ion collision data.

European AI for Fundamental Physics Conference, Amsterdam; April 2024;

Talk: AI-driven exploration of strongly interacting nuclear matter under extreme conditions.

ML for Jets Workshop Hamburg; Nov 2023;

Talk: ParticleGrow: Event-by-event simulation of HIC via autoregressive point cloud generation.

Dense Nuclear Matter EoS from Heavy-Ion Collisions, Seattle; Dec 2022;

Talk: The EoS of dense nuclear matter from Bayesian analysis of heavy-ion collision data.

International Conference on Ultra-relativistic Nucleus-Nucleus Collisions, Krakow; April 2022;

Poster: Deep Learning the physics of heavy-ion collisions at the CBM experiment using PointNet.

NA61 Collaboration meeting, CERN; Feb 2020;

Talk: Deep learning for fast TPC data processing.
